column1:
Geography

East Lothian is bounded to the west by the City of Edinburgh
column2: to the north by the estuary of the River Forth
column3:
to the east by the North Sea and to the south by the Lammermuir Hills which rise to 535m (1755 feet) at Meikle Says Law on the boundary with the Scottish Borders Council area.

Two parallel geological fault lines 1¼ miles (2 km) apart traverse East Lothian from southwest to northeast
column4: the Dunbar-Gifford fault and the Lammermuir fault. To the north of the former
column5: the landscape is characterised by rolling farmland
column6: sandy beaches and the distinctive pyramid of Berwick Law (187m / 613 feet) and the whale-backed Traprain Law (224m / 734 feet) which are of volcanic origin. To the south of the latter
column9:
giving rise to notable coastal cliff formations that are home to colonies of sea birds.

East Lothian is bisected by one main river
column11: which flows SW-NE to meet the North Sea west of Dunbar. It is joined by numerous tributaries which flow down from the Lammermuirs where there are three reservoirs
column12: the largest being Whiteadder Reservoir. To the west the River Esk makes a brief appearance en route to join the Firth of Forth at Musselburgh and in the east near Stenton is Pressmennan Loch
column13:
created in 1819.

East Lothian benefits from a mild climate with some of the lowest rainfall in Scotland. Over 57% of the area is given over to arable farming
column15: grassland (12%) and moorland (9%). There are 21 designated Sites of Scientific Interest
column16: including locations such as the Bass Rock and Danskine Loch
column17:
in addition to Aberlady Bay Local Nature Reserve and John Muir Country Park.

Between 1951 and 1991
column18: the population of East Lothian increased from 52

column1:
History

The history of East Lothian has been influenced by its proximity to the mouth of the Forth estuary and its position on the main routeways to Edinburgh skirting either side of the Lammermuirs
column2: the ruins of sizeable castles such as Tantallon
column3: Dirleton and Dunbar occupying strategic locations. Evidence of early occupation is to be found in the Iron Age settlements in the northern foothills of the Lammermuirs at sites such as White Castle and The Chesters
column4:
while the famous Traprain Law hoard of silver is associated with the brief presence of the Romans in the Lothians.

Religious foundations such as Nunraw Abbey and the Collegiate Church of Haddington indicate the growth of church landholdings during the Middle Ages and country houses such as Lennoxlove and Yester represent important country estates of a later period. East Lothian was in the forefront of the Agricultural Revolution during the 18th and 19th centuries when landowners reclaimed land
column6:
introduced crop rotations and created planned estate villages such as Ormiston.

Formerly known as Haddingtonshire
column7: East Lothian was one of the four districts of Lothian region between 1975 and 1996.

column1:
Industry

East Lothian's economy is focused on agriculture and farm land occupies 88% of the council's territory. The Council itself is the largest employer with around 4
column7:
scientific research and printing are also important to the economy.

Tourism continues to grow
column8: with historic buildings and the coastal towns maintaining their popularity
column10: such as the Scottish Seabird Centre in North Berwick
column11: are generating significant interest. Aberlady Bay and the John Muir Country Park provide coastal walking and birdwatching. The links also provide some of the best golf courses in Scotland
column12:
with Muirfield regularly hosting the Open Championship. Throughout the summer there are festivals and agricultural shows in many of the region's towns and villages.

Although previously a major employer in the west of the region
column13: there is no longer any deep mining for coal
column14:
with activity now centred around the open cast site at Blindwells (Tranent). Quarrying includes sizeable limestone workings at East Barns which is processed on-site into cement.

Fishing
column15: previously a key industry in Musselburgh
column18:
is no longer a significant economic activity.

Unemployment is well below the national average.
